title: Kenya: Kenya Airways Losses Point to Mismanagement
text:
Kenya Airways Losses Point to Mismanagement Tagged: opinion By Collins Mabinda 
There is a worrying trend that is going on in Kenya. Once renowned and reputed companies are making huge losses, and in the process, draining taxpayers money. The latest entrant in this infamous league is Kenya Airways, which was once touted as the best Airlines in Africa. The airline is now a shell of its former self, and the management has announced the company needs at least Sh50 billion to recover. 
Why is it that once fledging Kenyan companies are failing left, right, and centre. The issue has to do with the management of resources. Related Topics Nigeria: 14 People Killed in Ebonyi Road Accident 
Even if we bail out Kenya Airways, how sure are we that the resources are going to be used in a fair and prudent manner? Reports show the quality of service in the airline has been deteriorating, as staff are demoralised, and underpaid. This has seen the airline being surpassed in both profits and prestige by regional airlines such as Ethiopia airlines and Rwanda airlines. 
What's more, Uchumi is on its death bed; Mumias Sugar is slowly recovering but is not out of the woods yet; while a host of other companies are in dire situations. Crucially, here's what we need to do about parastatals in Kenya - we must first of all acknowledge that our auditors have not been exactly telling us the truth. In other countries, economic crimes attract maximum jail sentences and fine, and it is a pity that in Kenya, we let those who squander public companies' money go off scot-free. We all remember the case of key managers of American companies such as Kennedy Lay of Enron, who was sent to jail to serve as a warning to those who engage in theft of public companies funds. 
People have invested and saved with the company. It saddens me that a management would be so cavalier as to see all these investments go to drain. It is no wonder that it is becoming increasingly difficult to convince a Kenyan to invest in stocks and securities. Why not just buy a plot of land instead, or construct some real estate, whose value will keep going up always, rather than investing in companies that may just collapse the next day? Kenya
